flashcards.front: What is a sequence data structure?
flashcards.back: A data structure used to store and perform operations on a collection of items in a specific order

flashcards.front: What is the static sequence interface?
flashcards.back: An interface for a sequence data structure with a fixed number of items

flashcards.front: What are the main operations supported by the static sequence interface?
flashcards.back: Build, length, iteration, get, and set
A data structure that can resize itself to accommodate a changing number of items

flashcards.front: What is the difference between an interface and a data structure?
flashcards.back: An interface specifies what operations can be performed, while a data structure provides a representation and algorithms for those operations

flashcards.front: What is the dynamic sequence interface?
flashcards.back: An interface for a sequence data structure that allows for adding and removing items at any position

flashcards.front: What are the main operations supported by the dynamic sequence interface?
flashcards.back: Build, length, iteration, get, set, insert before, insert after, delete before, and delete after
A data structure where items are stored in nodes connected by pointers

flashcards.front: How does a linked list implement the getat operation?
flashcards.back: By following the next pointers from the head of the list to the desired node

flashcards.front: How does a linked list implement the setat operation?
flashcards.back: By updating the item in the node corresponding to the desired position

flashcards.front: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in a linked list?
flashcards.back: Constant for getat and setat at any position, but linear for iterating through all elements
A data structure with a fixed size that can store a collection of items of the same type

flashcards.front: What are the advantages of using a static array?
flashcards.back: Fast access to specific elements due to their contiguous memory allocation

flashcards.front: What are the disadvantages of using a static array?
flashcards.back: Cannot change the size of the array once it is created, leading to wasted space or out-of-bounds errors
A data structure that can resize itself as items are added or removed

flashcards.front: How does a dynamic array implement adding an item at the end?
flashcards.back: By allocating more memory and copying existing elements to the new location

flashcards.front: How does a dynamic array implement removing an item from the end?
flashcards.back: By decreasing the size of the array and moving remaining items to fill the gap left by the removed item
